item.title: Stablecoins Are Inevitable
item.description: While financial innovations often emerge on the system’s periphery, beyond the reach of regulation, if they prove to be systemically important, they end up being integrated into the system’s regulated core. Stablecoins are likely to follow this trajectory.

item.title: How Democracies Learn to Goose-Step
item.description: Democracies rarely collapse in a single blow. The shift toward authoritarianism often unfolds through a series of small, seemingly trivial steps that become consequential once social pressures push citizens to fall in line.

item.title: The Right Way to Rebuild Gaza’s Health System
item.description: Palestinians are already leading efforts to rebuild the health system in Gaza. The question now is whether the international community will support them by delivering emergency assistance – such as restoring access to fuel, water, and medical supplies – in ways that strengthen local institutions and governance.

item.title: The G20 Must Help Africa Escape the Financial Death Trap
item.description: US President Donald Trump’s tariff war has hindered progress on sustainable development in African countries – a process that has long been stymied by global inequalities. To address this issue, the G20 must maintain the momentum of South Africa’s presidency and push for a much-needed overhaul of international trade and finance.

item.title: Will the AI Boom Continue?
item.description: Amid growing concerns about an AI bubble, Nvidia’s stellar third-quarter earnings report has reinvigorated faith in the industry and the opportunities the technology represents. But as the money pours in, the risks to jobs, governance, and the planet continue to mount.

item.title: The Big Picture
Can AI Be Asia’s Next Growth Engine?
item.description: Asia’s growth model is under intense strain, and rapid population aging will only make matters worse. But, by fostering the skills people need to make use of AI and building institutions that enable them to apply those skills creatively, Asia's economies can unlock new sources of inclusive, durable growth.

item.title: Is Russia’s Hybrid War on Europe Becoming Conventional?
item.description: From arson attacks on civilian targets to the recent bombing of a rail line between Warsaw and Ukraine, Russian provocations inside Poland are intensifying. By stoking anti-Ukrainian and anti-EU sentiment, the Kremlin hopes to empower the "useful idiots" of the Polish populist right.

item.title: Academic Predators
item.description: The recently disclosed email exchanges between convicted pedophile Jeffrey Epstein and renowned economist Larry Summers illustrate a predatory dynamic in academia, in which professional support is implicitly traded for sex. A more equitable future requires an academic culture that repudiates the perverse norms of the old boys’ club.

item.title: Europe Must Help Africa Break the Cycle of Debt
item.description: Unsustainable debt burdens, rising borrowing costs, and escalating climate shocks have left African economies with little fiscal space to invest in their future. Without a comprehensive reform of the global financial system, the continent’s development and Europe’s stability will face growing risks.

item.title: The Case for Taxing AI
item.description: If AI causes mass unemployment or severe fiscal shocks, elected officials and policymakers will need to act fast to limit the disruption. Fortunately, some of the most reliable and powerful options are also the most familiar.

item.title: Only Liberal Nationalism Can Defeat the Far Right
item.description: Convinced that nationalism belongs to the past, liberals have largely abandoned appeals to cultural identity, allowing far-right political entrepreneurs to fill the void. To counter exclusionary nationalism, liberals must craft a unifying creed that restores a sense of shared destiny.

item.title: How Progressives Can Win on Immigration
item.description: For rudderless center-left parties, the debate around asylum and immigration should be seen not as a necessary evil, but as a political opportunity. By anchoring tougher enforcement in an authentic social-democratic agenda, the left can show that it has better solutions than the far right.

item.title: Let a Thousand AI Regimes Bloom
item.description: While critics of decentralized technology regulation warn of higher compliance costs for businesses, Chinese-style centralization is hardly preferable. In fact, not only do regulatory patchworks tend to converge, but they also provide the flexibility that rapid technological change demands.

item.title: Regional Leadership on Global Tipping Points
item.description: Climate tipping points can seem like science fiction, making them difficult to monitor and mitigate. To ensure that tipping-point dynamics are a central consideration in infrastructure planning, financial regulation, and development policy, regional bodies must develop the capacity to track and respond to them.

item.title: Why the US Economy Has Remained Stronger Than Expected
item.description: Although most economists have issued dire warnings about the damage tariffs and other ill-advised policies would cause, the US economy’s aggregate indicators have remained quite robust. Some of the costs may simply have been postponed, but rapid advances in AI could well offset them when they fall due.

item.title: Restoring Europe’s Social Contracts
item.description: Since World War II, liberal democracies have built and sustained their social contracts on three mutually reinforcing pillars: freedom, prosperity, and the rule of law. If Europe is to thrive in the 21st century and continue to serve as a model of democratic values, it must reinvigorate all three.

item.title: Sri Lanka’s Interest-Rate Trap
item.description: The Central Bank of Sri Lanka has inexplicably maintained high interest rates in a deflationary environment, which increases debt-service costs and suppresses economic activity. It must change course now, because austerity in the name of fiscal sustainability is self-defeating if it destroys the conditions for growth.

item.title: The Illiberal World Order Is Here
item.description: Now that Donald Trump's administration has explicitly rejected the international rules-based institutions and arrangements that America created after World War II, the very idea of an international order is no longer relevant. The world now belongs to illiberal regimes intent on pursuing their own interests.

item.title: The G20 Can No Longer Postpone Debt Relief
item.description: The idea that Africa can finance the green transition while simultaneously spending huge sums on debt service is absurd. That is why the upcoming G20 summit in Johannesburg must end with a commitment to restructuring the liabilities of highly indebted countries, most of which are on the continent.
